results.title: The Little Colonel
results.creator_credit: David Butler, B G De Sylva Productions and Fox Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
After a blistery Southern Colonel (Lionel Barrymore) banishes his daughter (Evelyn Venable) for marrying a Northener (John Lodge), he refuses to see her even when she returns years later with her young daughter (Shirley Temple). As outspoken as her grandfather, the ingenious child turns on plenty of charm and wins his heart. Includes a remarkable tap dance/soft-shoe routine with the famous Bill “Mr Bojangles” Robinson. In a role she makes her own, Hattie McDaniel of “Gone with the wind” fame, plays Mammy. The original production was in black and white, with the final scene shot in technicolor, however this version has been computer colourised.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Butler, B G De Sylva Productions and Fox Films

results.title: Film work
results.creator_credit: John Hughes and Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit.
results.brief_description: This film recalls the work of the Waterside Workers’ Federation Film Unit. Financed by several trade unions, the Unit produced eleven (mainly documentary) films between 1953-58. There are excerpts from four of the films ‘Pensions for Veterans’, ‘The Hungry Miles’, ‘November Victory’ and ‘Hewers of Coal’ and interviews with the Unit members, Keith Gow, Norma Disher and Jock Levy. (Awards: ATOM 1982)

results.title: Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm
results.creator_credit: Allan Dwan, Darryl F. Zanuck and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
Shirley Temple sings, dances and charms her way into everyone’s hearts in this acclaimed version of the Kate Douglas Wiggins story. When orphan Rebecca, (Shirley Temple), auditions for a radio show and doesn’t get the job, her stepfather, (William Demarest), takes her to live with Aunt Miranda, (Helen Westley), owner of Sunnybrook Farm. However, the show’s talent agent, (Randolph Scott), was prepared to hire Rebecca and begins to search frantically for the missing youngster - unaware the pint-sized radio star lives next door! This is a colourised version of the original black and white film.

results.title: Film graphics: abstract aspect of editing
results.creator_credit: Barry Spinello, Paul Aratow and Cine Qua Non-Bartholomus
results.brief_description: With pictures, animation and quotations from classical cinema, this film shows some of the basic structural principles of film composition and editing. Extracts from BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN, UN CHIEN ANDALOU, and MAN WITH A MOVIE CAMERA, show the use of abstract graphic structure in film editing.

results.title: Bright eyes
results.creator_credit: David Butler, Sol Wurtzel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
The first big film created especially for her, ‘Bright eyes’ helped make Shirley Temple a huge box-office star and features her most famous song, ‘On the good ship Lollipop’. The little darling of a group of aviators, Shirley splits her time between her pilot Godfather, Loop and her long-suffering mother who is a housemaid for a selfish, wealthy family. When a tragic accident suddenly leaves Shirley orphaned, Loop sets out to adopt Shirley - until he learns that he is not the only one determined to keep the adorable youngster. This is a colourized version of the original black and white film.

results.title: Heidi
results.creator_credit: Allan Dwan, Darryl F. Zanuck and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
Shirley Temple portrays the spirited young heroine of Johanna Spyri’s popular children’s novel giving her rich emotion and infinte charm. When her Aunt tires of caring for her, orphan Heidi is taken to the Swiss mountains to live with her gruff grandfather (Jean Hersholt), a hermit who comes to adore her. However, the Aunt returns to steal Heidi and sells her to a family whose invalid daughter (Marcia Mae Jones) needs a companion. Bullied by an evil governess (Mary Nash), Heidi still charms the entire household and never stops trying to return to her beloved grandfather. Colourised version.

results.title: Film Australia: immigration
results.creator_credit: Penelope McDonald, Paul Byrnes, Oasis DVD and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The Australian Migration scheme and Film Australia were both set up just after World War II and were under the one minister. Hand in hand they set about promoting and encouraging migration through the film medium. Films where also made to encourage acceptance of migrants for Australians. To this day the Film Australia Collection holds over 100 immigration films. This interesting and informative DVD presents edited versions of eight of the collections most important films. The films cover a period of time from the forties to the nineties with a contemporary short documentary containing interviews with some of the participants and the film makers of each of the eight films. “Film Australia Immigration” also presents a series of clips arranged by subjects such as language, food, and identity. An extremely fascinating and authoritative exploration of immigration in Australia.

results.title: Film appreciation: nature of the film medium
results.creator_credit: Bruce Baker, Simon Scanlon, Karl Holtsnider and OFM Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the flexibility of film presentation, the uses of variation in camera speed, camera movement and angle, subjective camera and symbolic techniques, illustrated by extracts. Features Ruth Hussey.
